column2: All but the crazy boy, Jake put in.
column3: All but the crazy boy, Jake put in.

column2: Ambrosch come along by the cornfield yesterday where I was at work and showed me three prairie dogs he'd shot. He asked me if they was good to eat.
column3: Ambrosch come along by the cornfield yesterday where I was at work and showed me three prairie dogs he'd shot. He asked me if they was good to eat.

column2: Grandmother looked up in alarm and spoke to grandfather.
column3: Grandmother looked up in alarm and spoke to grandfather.

column2: Fuchs put in a cheerful word and said prairie dogs were clean beasts and ought to be good for food, but their family connections were against them. I asked what he meant, and he grinned and said they belonged to the rat family.
column3: Fuchs put in a cheerful word and said prairie dogs were clean beasts and ought to be good for food, but their family connections were against them. I asked what he meant, and he grinned and said they belonged to the rat family.

column2: After breakfast grandmother and Jake and I bundled ourselves up and climbed into the cold front wagon-seat.
column3: After breakfast grandmother and Jake and I bundled ourselves up and climbed into the cold front wagon seat.

column2: As we approached the Shimerdas' we heard the frosty whine of the pump and saw Antonia, her head tied up and her cotton dress blown about her, throwing all her weight on the pump-handle as it went up and down.
column3: As we approached the Shimerdas' we heard the frosty whine of the pump and saw Antonia, her head tied up and her cotton dress blown about her, throwing all her weight on the pump handle as it went up and down.

column2: We went slowly up the icy path toward the door sunk in the drawside.
column3: We went slowly up the icy path toward the door sunk in the drawside.

column2: As soon as we entered he threw a grainsack over the crack at the bottom of the door.
column3: As soon as we entered he threw a grainsack over the crack at the bottom of the door.

column2: The air in the cave was stifling, and it was very dark, too.
column3: The air in the cave was stifling, and it was very dark, too.

column2: Then the poor woman broke down.

column2: Grandmother paid no heed to her, but called Antonia to come and help empty the basket.
column3: Grandmother paid no heed to her, but called Antonia to come and help empty the basket.

column2: Tony left her corner reluctantly.

column2: I had never seen her crushed like this before.

column2: You not mind my poor mamenka, Mrs. Burden.	You not mind my poor mamenka, mrs Burden.

column2: Yulka, he said in a low, despairing voice, "Yulka; my Antonia!"
column3: Yulka, he said in a low, despairing voice, "Yulka; my Antonia!"

column2: Grandmother drew back.

column2: You mean they sleep in there,--your girls? He bowed his head.

column2: Tony slipped under his arm.

column2: You'll have a better house after while, Antonia, and then you'll forget these hard times."

column2: He left Bohemia with more than a thousand dollars in savings, after their passage money was paid.
column3: He left Bohemia with more than a thousand dollars in savings, after their passage money was paid.

column2: Marek slid cautiously toward us and began to exhibit his webbed fingers.
column3: Marek slid cautiously toward us and began to exhibit his webbed fingers.

column2: I knew he wanted to make his queer noises for me--to bark like a dog or whinny like a horse,--but he did not dare in the presence of his elders.
column3: I knew he wanted to make his queer noises for me-to bark like a dog or whinny like a horse,--but he did not dare in the presence of his elders.

column2: Marek was always trying to be agreeable, poor fellow, as if he had it on his mind that he must make up for his deficiencies.
column3: Marek was always trying to be agreeable, poor fellow, as if he had it on his mind that he must make up for his deficiencies.

column2: The woman had a quick ear, and caught up phrases whenever she heard English spoken.
column3: The woman had a quick ear, and caught up phrases whenever she heard English spoken.

column2: As we rose to go, she opened her wooden chest and brought out a bag made of bed-ticking, about as long as a flour sack and half as wide, stuffed full of something.
column3: As we rose to go, she opened her wooden chest and brought out a bag made of bed ticking, about as long as a flour sack and half as wide, stuffed full of something.

column2: At sight of it, the crazy boy began to smack his lips.

column2: When Mrs. Shimerda opened the bag and stirred the contents with her hand, it gave out a salty, earthy smell, very pungent, even among the other odors of that cave.
column3: When mrs Shimerda opened the bag and stirred the contents with her hand, it gave out a salty, earthy smell, very pungent, even among the other odors of that cave.
